intro: Thymus kirgisorum, commonly known as Kirghiz thyme, is a perennial herb native to Central Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic essential oils and square stems. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in temperate climates. Its small, pink or purple flowers bloom in early summer, attracting pollinators like bees. The leaves are used in traditional medicine and as a spice, similar to other thyme species.
